description: From Late Middle English defilen (‚Äúto make dirty, befoul; to contaminate (the body or an organ) with dirt or disease; to pollute morally or spiritually; to desecrate, profane; to violate (the sanctity of marriage, an agreement or oath, etc.); to rape; to slander; to abuse; to destroy; to injure; to treat unfairly, oppress‚Äù)¬†[and other forms], a variant of defoulen (‚Äúto make dirty, defile, pollute; to contaminate (the body or an organ) with dirt or disease; to pollute morally or spiritually; to desecrate, profane; to violate (the sanctity of marriage, an agreement or oath, etc.); to have sexual intercourse with; to rape; etc.‚Äù) (compare also defoilen). Defoulen is derived from Old French defouler (‚Äúto trample; to oppress; to outrage; to pollute; to violate‚Äù), from de- (prefix indicating actions are done more strongly or vigorously) + fouler (‚Äúto trample, tread on; to mistreat, oppress‚Äù), foler (‚Äúto destroy; to mistreat‚Äù) (from Vulgar Latin fullare (‚Äúto full (make cloth denser and firmer by soaking, beating, and pressing)‚Äù), from Latin full≈ç (‚Äúperson who fulls cloth, fuller‚Äù); further etymology uncertain, possibly from Proto-Indo-European *b ∞leh‚ÇÉ- (‚Äúto blow; to inflate, swell; to bloom, flower‚Äù) or Etruscan êåñêåãêåñêåò (fulu)). The English word is analysable as de- (intensifying prefix) +‚Äé file (‚Äú(archaic) to corrupt; to defile‚Äù).

The Middle English word defilen was probably formed from defoulen on the analogy of befilen (‚Äúto make dirty, befoul; to corrupt; to violate one's chastity; to desecrate; to slander‚Äù) and befoulen (‚Äúto make dirty, befoul; to violate one's chastity; to vilify‚Äù),, respectively from filen (‚Äúto make foul, impure, or unclean, pollute; to pollute morally or spiritually; to desecrate, profane; to have sexual intercourse with; to rape; etc.‚Äù) and foulen (‚Äúto make dirty, pollute; to become dirty; to defecate; to deface or deform; to pollute morally or spiritually; to damage, injure; to destroy; to treat unfairly, oppress; to tread on, trample‚Äù). Filen and foulen are respectively from Old English f»≥lan (‚Äúto befoul, defile, pollute‚Äù) and f≈´lian (‚Äúto foul‚Äù), both from Proto-West Germanic *f≈´lijan (‚Äúto make dirty, befoul‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *f≈´lijanƒÖ (‚Äúto make dirty, befoul‚Äù), from *f≈´laz (‚Äúdirty, foul; rotten‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *puH- (‚Äúfoul; rotten‚Äù).

verbs.description: defile (third-person singular simple present defiles, present participle defiling, simple past and past participle defiled)

entries.meaning: To make (someone or something) physically dirty or unclean; to befoul, to soil.
examples: Synonyms: contaminate, pollute, spoil, sully; see also Thesaurus:dirty
Antonyms: clean, purify; see also Thesaurus:make clean

entries.meaning: To make (someone or something) morally impure or unclean; to corrupt, to tarnish.
To act inappropriately towards or vandalize (something sacred or special); to desecrate, to profane.
examples: Antonyms: hallow, sanctify; see also Thesaurus:consecrate
To urinate on someone‚Äôs grave is an example of a way to defile it.

entries.meaning: (religion) To cause (something or someone) to become ritually unclean.

examples: The serial rapist kidnapped and defiled a six-year-old girl.

entries.meaning: To deprive (someone) of their sexual chastity or purity, often not consensually; to deflower, to rape.
examples: The serial rapist kidnapped and defiled a six-year-old girl.

entries.meaning: To cause uncleanliness; specifically, to pass feces; to defecate.

description: The verb is borrowed from French d√©filer (‚Äúto march; to parade‚Äù), from d√©- (prefix indicating actions are done more strongly or vigorously) + one or both of the following:
The noun is borrowed from French d√©fil√© (‚Äúparade, procession‚Äù), a noun use of the past participle of d√©filer (verb); see above.

entries.meaning: A narrow passage or way (originally (military), one which soldiers could only march through in a single file or line), especially a narrow gorge or pass between mountains.
An act of marching in files or lines.
A single file of soldiers; (by extension) any single file.

verbs.description: defile (third-person singular simple present defiles, present participle defiling, simple past and past participle defiled) (military, also figuratively)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, archaic) To march in a single file or line; to file.
(transitive, obsolete) To march across (a place) in files or lines.

description: The verb is borrowed from French d√©filer (‚Äúto arrange soldiers or fortify (something) as a protection from enfilading fire; to unthread‚Äù) (compare Middle French desfilher (‚Äúto unthread‚Äù)), from d√©- (prefix meaning ‚Äònot‚Äô) + enfiler (‚Äúto rake with gunfire, enfilade; to string on to a thread; to thread (a needle)‚Äù) (from en- (prefix meaning ‚Äòin, into; on, on to‚Äô) + filer (verb) or file (noun); see etymology 2).
The noun is derived from the verb.

entries.meaning: (military, rare) An act of defilading a fortress or other place, or of raising the exterior works in order to protect the interior.

verbs.description: defile (third-person singular simple present defiles, present participle defiling, simple past and past participle defiled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, military, rare) Synonym of defilade (‚Äúto fortify (something) as a protection from enfilading fire‚Äù)
